channel.title: At what point will the internet (specifically broadband) be free of charge
channel.description:
Will it ever be free or will they keep upping the prices and make me pay £25 a month for broadband?
Also, what provider are you on?
Aol for me.

item.title: At what point will the internet (specifically broadband) be free of charge
item.dc:creator: @xryz xryz
item.description:
@xryz wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:40, topic:515366”][quote author=thakillah link=topic=633618.msg4282289#msg4282289 date=1365837410]

Nothing is truly free in life, a cost is always there.

love is free :3
[/quote]
No it isn’t. You have to work for it.[/quote]
it depends on your meaning of free.

Most would think if I don’t have to spend any money on a good/service then it is free to them. Sure it it may be free to you but with the way currency and trade works it costs someone something along the line considering anyone with the choice would never work for free.

Now if you define free by meaning that nothing was done to obtain something then sure nothing can truly be free except for the state of existence. but love in an aspect can be free as in Storge love(the kind of love parents have for their children). The parents didn’t work to love the child and the child didn’t work to be loved yet the love is present.

I think as a world community we should take this economic crisis and instead of take years or decades to recover or draw out the suffering of everyone just to follow the principles of trade and currency or even agreeing to have a world wide currency reset we should just agree to get rid of the idea of currency altogether. This would take a lot of planning, and work to execute but would put humanity in a better standing and even increase our productivity and technological advances. Everyone would have more opportunity. Everyone would just live better lives because everyone would be able to go to bed full and with a roof over their head. I was thinking everyone could work 20 hour weeks(5 hours a day 4 days a week. and the basic layout for the week would be work 2 days, rest a day, work 2 more days, 2 day “weekend”, and repeat). working 20 hours a week would be all that is required to be able to be able to eat and have a place to call home, while also have the ability to have plenty of personal time to spend with family or friends. People wouldn’t be able to hoard things because they would have an allowance on how many items one can have for enjoyment or luxury; after that amount is reached they most trade it in for something else. Everything would be quality made to last because fixing things is a waste of time and since currency doesn’t exist no profit can be gained on fixing broken things.

Also sure star trek is fictional but it can still be used to help better society as a whole and in star trek they don’t have money and they aren’t paid to work, they work for the betterment of the community which is what we all should strive to think like because we would be better off if we did so.

don’t mean to got off topic here but about your signature you may want to understand the meaning of well-regulated. Also the second amendment should be broken into 2 sentence since most people think both parts go together when they really don’t. It should be read as, “A well regulated Militia, being necessary to the security of a free State. The right of the people to keep and bear Arms, shall not be infringed.” because that is how the founder intended it to be read. http://constitution.org/cons/wellregu.htm http://www.guncite.com/gc2ndmea.html If there is to be a conversation started about this there is no need to reply, you can start a thread in the appropriated section or send a message.

Read full topic

item.title: At what point will the internet (specifically broadband) be free of charge
item.dc:creator: @xryz xryz
item.description:
@xryz wrote:

I don’t know how long it will take for internet to be free. probably a while decades at least. As long as someone thinks they can make a profit off something it won’t be free.

I have comcast internet + economy tv(which has all the channels I like) for $60/m which include the all the fee including rent for the modem and tv box. The speed is supposed to be 50+ Mbps and this is what I get
edit: I forgot to mention that is with a special deal that should be finished this month I believe so I will now pay $72+all the fees.

Read full topic

item.title: At what point will the internet (specifically broadband) be free of charge
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

Any Canadians here with DSL internet? (specifically ontario or quebec)

I still have full access to all my tools with Bell, and I’d be happy to look at your line conditions and speed profiles. I may even be able to improve your speeds/service. Just PM me the phone number that the dsl is working off of, and I will look it up.

item.dc:creator: @marcbob marcbob
item.description:
@marcbob wrote:

I have wowway which is a more local company to the northeast states. It’s good and all but the internet could be much faster if we simply switched to xfinity by comcast. The price would be about the same but my parents are too lazy to have to get a new email address and have everything switched over to that one.

item.source: At what point will the internet (specifically broadband) be free of charge

item.title: At what point will the internet (specifically broadband) be free of charge
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

Anyone in England, never buy broadband from BT. My granddad went over his download limit (5GB/month) and they sent him an email saying that his internet speed would be reduced for a month. Fair enough, he’d gone over the limit. Three months later and it had been getting slower every month, he phones them and is told that due to line restrictions in his area it wasn’t possible for the speed to be increased at all.

Scum

Read full topic

item.title: At what point will the internet (specifically broadband) be free of charge
item.dc:creator: @imthenull imthenull
item.description:
@imthenull wrote:

fiber.google.com

Google Fiber | High Speed Internet Service & TV

Google Fiber offers super fast Internet up to 1,000 megabits per second. Sign up for high speed Internet, TV, & phone today.

Free Internet $0/mo $300 construction fee (one time or $25/mo for 12 mo)

sounds good to me, too bad it’s not nation wide/global

item.title: At what point will the internet (specifically broadband) be free of charge
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

There has been free access to the internet for years, many dialup providers offered it for free.

[quote=“Arcik, post:14, topic:515366”]Virgin media - I pay £10 for broadband, phone lines and tv < they actually doubled my broadband free of charge. Its actually a really good plan!

I get free land lines and I use my mobile for mobile calls.[/quote]

£10 Won’t be your final bill, they charge £15 alone a month for line rental.

item.title: At what point will the internet (specifically broadband) be free of charge
item.dc:creator: @si_force Si Force
item.description:
@si_force wrote:

I’d like to hope that the internet will be free one day, but I doubt it’ll be any soon. I’d say one country will introduce free internet for their residents and it’ll slowly catch on.

I’m with vodafone for my internet service at the moment. It’s terribly slow sometimes and is just a bad deal in general.
